answers.text:
Hello,
I have found some information that might help with your question. In Virginia the most recent information shows no local governments have posted their PACE plans yet.
 I did find a site dedicated to purely commercial PACE projects which I have included below.
http://pacenow.org/blog/commercial-pace/
Also, I found a site that lists major PACE financing plans in a variety of states. A lot of these places have project beyond commercial ones but the list still might offer some assistance.
http://en.openei.org/wiki/PACE_Financing
Additionally, the articles below have more general information about the success and benefits of PACE financing models.
http://icma.org/en/Article/101185/New_DOE_Report_Examines_Local_PACE_Financing_Identifies_Positive_Economic_Impacts
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301610/Presentation_on_Property_Assessed_Clean_Energy_Bonds
I hope these help!
Ali Iannolo
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Anne Lewis
text:
New energy efficiency financing models have enormous potential to catalyze demand from both owners and lenders for clean-energy investment in buildings.  PACE financing is a model that would be administered by local governments and could allow property owners to undertake energy efficiency, renewable energy, and water efficiency projects without large up-front payments.  PACE "districts" would essentially be special taxing districts that would allow local governments to provide capital for energy and water improvements in buildings.  The outlay for projects is secured by a property lien and is repaid by the owner as a voluntary special assessment on the property tax bill over a 5- to 20-year term.  The General Assembly has approved enabling legislation for Virginia localities to consider such a program.  
I am interested in hearing about localities (especially in Virginia) who are doing this or considering it for commercial only (not residential).
title: PACE (Property-Assessed Clean Energy) Financing programs
